inputs.name: esPath
inputs.label: ElasticSearch path
inputs.helpMarkDown: The location of where ElasticSearch is installed. Example: C:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib\elastic\tools\elasticsearch-1.5.1

inputs.name: serviceName
inputs.label: Service name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the service instance of ElasticSearch

inputs.name: isMaster
inputs.label: Master node
inputs.helpMarkDown: Allow this node to be eligible as a master node (enabled by default)

inputs.name: dataStored
inputs.label: Store data
inputs.helpMarkDown: Allow this node to store data (enabled by default)

inputs.name: dataPath
inputs.label: Data folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to directory where to store index data allocated for this node.

inputs.name: amountShards
inputs.label: Amount of shards
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set the number of shards (splits) of an index

inputs.name: amountReplicas
inputs.label: Amount of replicas
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set the number of replicas (additional copies) of an index

inputs.name: hostIp
inputs.label: IP address
inputs.helpMarkDown: Elasticsearch, by default, binds itself to the 0.0.0.0 address, and listens on port [9200-9300] for HTTP traffic and on port [9300-9400] for node-to-node communication. (the range means that if the port is busy, it will automatically try the next port).

inputs.name: httpPort
inputs.label: Port
inputs.helpMarkDown: Elasticsearch, by default, binds itself to the 0.0.0.0 address, and listens on port [9200-9300] for HTTP traffic and on port [9300-9400] for node-to-node communication. (the range means that if the port is busy, it will automatically try the next port).

inputs.name: tcpPort
inputs.label: TCP Port
inputs.helpMarkDown: Elasticsearch, by default, binds itself to the 0.0.0.0 address, and listens on port [9200-9300] for HTTP traffic and on port [9300-9400] for node-to-node communication. (the range means that if the port is busy, it will automatically try the next port).

inputs.name: unicasthosts
inputs.label: Unicast hosts
inputs.helpMarkDown: Other hosts ElasticSearch should check to discover more nodes. Example: "host1", "host2:port

inputs.name: minimumMasters
inputs.label: Minimum amount of master nodes
inputs.helpMarkDown: This setting tells Elasticsearch to not elect a master unless there are enough master-eligible nodes available. Only then will an election take place. This setting should always be configured to a quorum (majority) of your master-eligible nodes. A quorum is (number of master-eligible nodes / 2) + 1

inputs.name: rejoinMasterGone
inputs.label: Rejoin when Master gone
inputs.helpMarkDown: Try to rejoin first when the master is gone, before declaring self as master
